Conceptually, is it correct to understand the proof this way? Suppose I have a quantum particle A having 50% chance of being in state X and 50% chance of in state Y. Indeed, I can “clone” by making another particle B with also 50% chance of being in state X and 50% chance of being in state Y. This would imply that the particles (A,B) might be in states (X,X) or (X,Y) or (Y,X) or (Y,Y) with equal probability. However, this is not cloning, for if B were a clone of A, A and B would necessarily have to be in the same state, i.e. (A,B) must be in either state (X,X) or (Y,Y). Is this understanding correct?

I do not understand why so much problem with the superposition of quantum states, you only need a scanner that is capable of generating a digital record of the position and identity of each of the atoms of the object or creature that you want to duplicate, then a printer that is able to use the atoms to recreate the original object using the digital record as a map. I prefer to use the word "cloning" strictly for the field of biology/genetics and so I think it is more appropriate and less confusing to use the word "duplication" for physics. It is true that creating a perfect duplicate instantly (with each of the positions of the atoms and particles exactly the same as the original) is certainly impossible but it is irrelevant. Those ultra-tiny differences don't matter because, even if they were to be duplicated perfectly, the "random" nature of the quantum world would make the perfect duplicate no longer a thousandths of a second later. The real problem with duplication I think is the printing speed together with the accuracy and speed of the scan (it would also take a lot of disk space to store the map of atoms that make up the entire body of a cat, for example, but at the rate that advances the technologies of the information storage I do not think that this becomes a problem). Then the duplicate generated, thanks to an exact map of even the positions of all the atoms and subatomic particles, would only be different from the original by being delayed a certain amount of time, seconds or minutes for example (whatever it takes for the printer to generate the duplicate) and this would only matter at the initial instant of the duplicate, since then the nature of the quantum and the entropy would make the possible minute differences irrelevant.

I would like to submit an idea of what might be a flaw in this thought process. Feel free to discuss below, this is just me dropping off an idea.
|A> = |A1> + |A2>
|B> = |B1> + |B2>
with
|A+B> = |A1> * |B1> + |A2> * |B2>
and
C(|X>) = |X>*|X>
Would result in
C(|A+B>) = |A+B>*|A+B> = (|A1*B1> + |A2>*|B2>) * (|A1*B1> + |A2>*|B2>) = (|A1>*|B1>) * (|A1>*|B1>) + 2 * (|A1>*|B1>) * (|A2>*|B2>) + (|A2>*|B2>) * (|A2>*|B2>)
with
|Z> = |A+B>
we have
|Z> = |Z1> + |Z2>
with
|Z1> = |(A+B)1> = |A1>*|B1>

Simplifying our original cloning procedure, we'd get
C(|A+B>) = |Z1>*|Z1> + |Z1>*|Z2> + |Z1>*|Z2> + |Z2>*|Z2>

However, our original cloning transformation is an incorrect view of the process.
C(|Z>) != |Z>*|Z>. Looking at this purely mathematical, you get an incorrect view of the transformation. This transformation is not a creation of two separate superpositions regardless of each other. It's a creation of a superposition of both objects together, similar to |A+B> itself. To say that it's truly |Z>*|Z> implies that the object (with two different subpositions) cloned creates a system of two objects which includes every possibility,. Every possibility. Including that the two items hold only one exact same quality. It's hard to say exactly what I'm trying to communicate, so please follow the math to understand better.

Alternatively, we could view it as the following:
|Z> = |A+B>.
Given
|Y> = |Z+Z>,
then
|Y> = |Z1>*|Z1> + |Z2>*|Z2>.
Then we can define our exact cloning procedure to be
C(|Z>) = |Y> = |Z + Z> = |Z1>*|Z1> + |Z2>*|Z2> = (|A1>*|B1>)*(|A1>*|B1>) + (|A2>*|B2>)*(|A2>*|B2>); which gives us either 2 of A1 and B1 or 2 of A2 and B2, not including the possibility, for instance, that the bomb went off but the cat is still alive, which is impossible given real situations.

I love the step by step logic, however, I believe there is an invalid assumption in this video that led to the wrong conclusion.
The assumption was made at 2:33 that multiple particles, or whatever, are the product of their components. While this may be true mathematically for vectors, it is not totally applicable to everything in the manner that it is suggested. For example, this works mathematically: |5> = |2> x |3> but notice that optically speaking, the number 5 looks very different from either the 2 or the 3 that produces it. Likewise, multiplying a |barrel> with a |cat> might produce something totally unexpected, like a bowl of spaghetti rather than a barrel next to a cat.
I think, it is more likely the case that the collection of a barrel and a cat should be represented as the sum of it's parts, not the product. Therefore, the product sign ("x") in the equation at 5:12 should be a plus sign ("+") instead, and in that case, the math does work out, and cloning can exist.
However, that being said, unless we can figure out how to control everything in the universe that might have an effect on something, we will likely never be able to clone it perfectly. Even if we could clone something for an instant, the two things would cease to be the same in the next instant because forces of the universe will be different at two points in space.

The problem with the Schrodinger's Cat analogy is that there is a period of time where the gunpowder has exploded but the cat is still alive, as that thing that kills the cat exists but has not yet reached the cat in order to kill it. It would still be constrained by the prohibition against exceeding the speed of information, more commonly known as the speed of light in a vacuum.
Obviously, the interior of the box holding both the gunpowder and the cat is not a vacuum, as placing the cat in a vacuum would kill the cat, making the state of the gunpowder irrelevant to the condition of the cat.
So, the cat and the gunpowder are clearly in a box with an atmosphere that has a composition and pressure that is breathable by the cat, which would further prolong the cat's life against that quality of exploding gunpowder that would kill it, because whatever it is about exploding gunpowder that is lethal to cats would have to first overcome the resistance provided by the atmosphere that allows the cat to live in the box once it is sealed in the first place, as well as traversing whatever intervening space that exists between the cat and the gunpowder when the latter explodes.

Okay, I know where this is going, what with the quantum identity of all the particles that make you what you are in the universe, but most talk of cloning is not about absolute perfection, but another being or object which shares the traits of the original to be physically and possibly mentally indistinguishable. No one is going to check my body double for the right quantum signature and no one beyond an actual quantum physicist is really looking for that. Your print-outs from a regular or indeed 3D printer are both equally-made objects from the same source which bear no characteristics different from one another. They fulfill the same exact role as they perform the same function, having been made identically. For art, there are reasons that any reproduction of, say, the Mona Lisa are legally required to be of a different size or not made with exactly the same materials. Art is required to remain unique for its value and purpose, per individual creations. To fraud it is to steal its identity, which is one of the reasons human cloning is forbidden. If we became advanced enough to simply copy a human being, the clone could replace the original, being indistinguishable on even the genetic level. The only way to get around that would be to leave markers that prove who the original is. But still, a copy of a thing - if made earnestly - is still its copy, quantum signatures or not. It may have the all-new four-wheel drive quantum identity with racing stripes, but if it looks like you and acts like you and it gets rid of you...it's going to be you from then on.

Proof by contradiction is a really effective way to get things like these across. For example, you can prove you can’t divide by zero by assuming you can, messing with that fact, and learn that if you can divide by zero, 1=2.

- Let’s say you can divide by 0.
- Every number out there that you can divide by has a multiplicative inverse, for example, the multiplicative inverse of the variable “n” is 1/n, and 1/n * n = 1.
- This means that 1/0 * 0 = 1.
- It also means that (1/0 * 0) + (1/0 * 0) = 2.
- Distributive property states you can turn the above equation into 1/0 * (0 + 0) = 2.
- 0 + 0 = 0
- 1/0 * 0 = 2
- 2 = 1

Hi, something seems off about the proof in the video - at the start you said that there are 3 things needed for cloning:
1) the original object (O)
2) the materials that comprise the object (M)
3) cloning process (C)

But the proof only considers O and C (as a function of O), while it should be O, M and C (as a function of O and M).
Cloning shouldn't be C(O)=OxO but C(OxM)=OxO.
If O exists in superposition as O1+O2 then cloning would be C((O1+O2)xM)=(O1+O2)x(O1+O2).
We then need to examine the cloning process for O1 and O2, however the materials needed for cloning O1, O2 and O might be different.
Let's say M1 is the materials for cloning O1 and M2 is the materials for cloning O2, so the materials needed for cloning O=O1+O2 are M=M1+M2.
C(O1xM1)=O1xO1,C(O2xM2)=O2xO2
O1xO1+O2xO2+O1xO2+O2xO1=(O1+O2)x(O1+O2)=OxO=C(OxM)=C((O1+O2)x(M1+M2))=C(O1xM1)+C(O1xM2)+C(O2xM1)+C(O2xM2)=O1xO1+O2xO2+C(O1xM2)+C(O2xM1)

So the process could exist so long as O1xO2+O2xO1=C(O1xM2)+C(O2xM1). Consider for example the trivial solution where M=O and cloning is an empty action.

So here's my $0.02: people who have seen the math behind quantum mechanics will already know it and not need an explanation. So your video is really aimed at the lay-person. Therefore I think you should spend a bit more time explaining what a superposition is, which is tricky. The way I would do it is: if we say that a thing in a superposition of |a> and |b>, then that means that when we look at it, some of the time (say, 36% of the time) we'll see |a>, and other times (64% in this case) we'll see |b>. And we write that as 0.36 |a> + 0.64 |b> (kinda).

What are a and b? They can be different values of whatever we're measuring: maybe different speeds, or positions, or energies. So, say, if we're measuring speed, some of the time we'll see the particle moving at 20m/s and other times at 37m/s. Add in the fact that, when we measure it, we destroy the superposition and the state becomes 100% the component you've observed (and none of the other ones). I think this is the part that really will go over the heads of those unfamiliar with the field, and what you should spend a bit more time explaining.

This doesn't disprove no perfect cloning in practice because in practice, the clone would be in a different location from the original, and therefore experiences different gravitational forces, electrostatic forces and so on with the rest of the universe. So when we say we want a perfect clone in practice, we are not saying we want a perfect clone that has the same location, etc. What we mean by a perfect clone in practice is a clone that is identical, part by part, when you only look at the parts within the system as though it is isolated from the rest of the universe. But since no system is really isolated, this doesn't disprove perfect cloning the way we mean it in practice.

If quantum cloning was possible, most constraints of quantum mechanics can be violated. To violate Heisenberg's uncertainty principle (HUP), simple clone the quantum particle so you can compromise on position and measure the momentum accurately for 1 particle and measure position on the other particle compromising on the accuracy of momentum. Now you have very accurate knowledge of position and momentum of the original particle enabled mainly by cloning, violating the HUP. Similarly with double-slit experiment if act of observing is affecting the results, then simply clone the quantum particle and perform the measurement on the cloned particle and preferably after the end of original experiment. Now you know the electron passed through e.g. the left slit right after interference pattern had been already observed - a violation of wave-particle duality again enabled by cloning. Hence nature/universe would never allow quantum-cloning, neither in theory nor in practice.

The reasoning in this video is wrong. (A+B)^2 = A^2 + B^2 iff A*B = 0, which makes sense, because there is no such thing as the gunpowder being both exploded and non-exploded, there's only a superposition of exploded and non-exploded, which is a+b, not a*b. Another problem is that you assume that cloning a thing means that you should clone the right hand side of the equation. However, if you're gonna clone A then at the end of the cloning the symbol A still refers to the original, not the clone. The clones are not supposed to be equal in every way: you want the two clones A and A' to be at a different location in space. Otherwise A and A' are not clones at all, because they refer to the same object!

I may be wrong, but I feel like the crux of this video rests primarily on the uncertainty principle. My brain can't decipher how the fuck the uncertainty principle works, but my basic understanding of it is that it means on a quantum level that the position and momentum of a particle cannot be simultaneously measured because it's (wavelength?) properties are elementally unpredictable. It has nothing to do with the inadequacy of our equipment, but is rather a fundamental working of the universe.

In other words, particles behave, on a quantum level, randomly within a range of probability. And therefore, if you ever attempted to make a perfect clone, you would be up against the inherent indeterminism of quantum mechanics. No matter how accurately you capture all of the variables at any given moment, the clone will always turn out differently due to quantum uncertainty. Though if the impact that quantum uncertainty has on a biological level is small enough as to be imperceptible by humans, then it wouldn't really matter. But I doubt that's the case, given that every atom in the human body has an infinite amount of random velocity and position possibilities. It seems like that degree of indeterminism would add up rather quickly.

(Interestingly enough, the uncertainty principle seems to suggest that the whole deterministic timeline theory is wrong. If there's intrinsic randomness in the universe, then any attempt to replay a section of the timeline would yield different results.)

Only 1:18 in, but I'm gonna say no, we can't clone anything that perfectly. The reason is simple: if all of the subatomic particles in two objects have the same properties at some point in time, then there can be only one such object; that is, if the momentum/position/spin of two electrons are exactly the same, then those electrons must occupy the same space, be travelling at the same speed, and be spinning the same way, but we know that can't happen (thanks, Pauli!) A much more interesting case to consider is whether the properties of subatomic particles comprising two objects can ever "coincide", however briefly. There would be, to my naive understanding, a single instant in time where the two objects "become one" before splitting into however many slightly different objects...

Now here is the bit nobody bothers to mention about quantum entanglement.  The quantum entanglement itself is a measurement.   Which means you always replace a qubit of data with a different qubit each time you quantumly entangle particles.   That itself is not a show stopper for teleportation, as you can design the process to control which qubit is measured.  So if you make sure the quantum information that is replaced with new random data is not part of the information you are trying to quantum teleport, then everything works out fine for making your perfect copies.   In truth there is probably a very small amount of quantum information associated with who I am.  You could probably destroy 99.999% of it in the teleportation process and still end-up with someone I would consider to still be me.   After all I'm constantly interacting with my environment.   Every atom of my body is constantly being measured with chemical processes...   The trick is though, learning what 0.001% really matters.

I am at one minute and thirty seconds into the video, and it is already clear you do NOT understand the no cloning theorem. No point in watching the rest, let me just explain what you got wrong...

The no cloning theorem does not mean you cannot make a perfect copy. It just means you cannot get two different results measuring the same state twice using your perfect copy. The two versions will evolve differently over time. In your sheep example, indeed both sheep would be exactly the same at the instant they were created. But an instant later, after untold number of quantum interactions they would be different.

Here is the thing, the rules for quantum entangement is simply that the first measurement of each quantumly entangled particle cannot give inconsistent results. So if I have two quantumly entangled photons A & B. I measure the polarization of A as 0 degrees, I will also measure B at 0 degrees. After that first measurement, they are no longer entangled. Which means if I turn the polarization filter for B 45 degrees, I can measure A at 0 degrees, and say B at 45 degrees. That is not an inconsistency as say a polarization of both could be 22.5 degrees to produce these results. However, here is the thing the measurement of B in this case told me nothing about A, and the measurement of A told me nothing about B. If I proceed to measure A a second time at the same angle as B, I can get the same results, but I can also get opposite results. For me to actually learn something about B that would effect my second measurement of A would violate the no-cloning theorem.

So what this tells me is the SHEEP indeed can be exactly identical at the instant of creation. But as soon as I start performing different measurements, they are no longer identical.

True, the proof shows that cloning is not possible if you want to clone any state. But that doesn't mean the only possible cloning is the trivial one when you know the state all along.

If you restrict your cloning device to work only on a subset of all possible states, then the cloning does work, provided the subset holds a simple relation (which is also hinted in the video). If you only want cloning for the states |a>, |b> or |c>, you need to make sure those products <a|b>, <b|c>, ... are zero.

In a nutshell, you can clone partly unknown states, as long as the possible states you put in are mutually orthogonal.

So, proof by contradiction establishes `P` by assuming `~P`, reaching a contradiction, and using double negation (`~~P => P`). What you've done is called 'proof of negation' (assume `P`, reach a contradiction; conclude `~P`). Proof by contradiction is (classically valid but) constructively invalid; proof of negation is classically and intuitionistically valid.

The kind of proof you are presenting here may be better off if you put it in the frame of a proof of the contrapositive. This kind of mathematical proof foolows the following form:
Theorem: A => B
Proof: NOT(B) => NOT(A) (which is equivalent)
In our case A would be "the distributive law applies to transformations". B is the statement "a cloning transformation does not exist". Basically, you prove: from the existence of a cloning transformation, it follows that the distributive law cannot apply to said transformation. Just put the proof explicitly in the frame of the contrapositive, and you will have a more focused and easier to understand argument, I blieve.

Great presentation of the 'No Cloning Theorem.'

However, I take issue with this presentation at the point in this explanation where he reassures "people who want to live in a 'SciFi' future" that just because perfect quantum cloning is not possible, does not mean teleportation is impossible.

His assertion that teleportation 'is'/'might' still be be possible regardless of the No Cloning Theorem makes the mistake of saying you put a person in a teleportation 'here-box' and add the materials to make the teleported person, then teleport--where the person disappears in the teleportation 'here-box,' and the person re-materializes in the teleportation 'there-box.'

The problem, I perceive, is why do you need all the extra material to build another person, when the original person to be teleported has all the material that is needed, essentially teleportation would mean deconstructing an existing human/animal/plant/mineral/thing to the maximum essential particles that are capable of being transmitted by some unknown means, and also sending the instructions for reassembling those particles into an exact clone of the original person. Or, it would mean deconstructing a person and transmitting the instruction to the teleportation 'there-box' that has the materials needed to reconstruct the original human perfectly.

Thus, either the original person does not need any extra material to be reassembled, i.e. the original person is both the person to be teleported, and the material for reconstruction, else the original person does not disappear in the teleportation 'here-box,' and reappear in the teleportation 'there-box,' unless the original person was deconstructed and the teleportation 'there-box' had all the materials, and instructions to perfectly reconstruct the original. Now after the perfect reconstruction, the state of the reconstruction may change and be totally different from the state of the original, and to teleport back to the original location would require the same process--be it just deconstruction and sending the information to reconstruct from material, or using the original material and actually sending it with reconstruction information.

That part bothered me in the video. I could be all wrong, I'm neither a physicist or mathematician, but the teleportation part bothered me, and the No Cloning Theorem seemed to also prove that teleportation would not be possible either.

Replace every '+' by 'or' and every '×' by 'and'

'(2+5)×(3+5)' is not the same as '5+(3×2)'
but '(2 or 5) and (3 or 5)' is the same as '5 or (2 and 3)'

(remember: without brackets, 'and' goes before 'or', but i still will use brackets in most cases)

Lets take A as the bomb. A1 is the bomb not having exploded, A2 is the bomb having exploded. B is the cat. B1 is the living cat, B2 is the dead cat.

Take a look at 4:18: (If my explanations are wrong or in case you don't understand them, blame my bad englisch and watch the video again, then you should understand and the solution should be right anyway)

1. |A> = |A1>+|A2>

The state of A is either that is has exploded or that it hasn't yet, so
|A>=|A1> or |A2>

2. |AB>=|A1>×|B1>+|A2>×|B2>

Either the bomb exploded and the cat died or the bomb hasn't exploded and the cat is still living, so
|A and B>=|A1> and |B1> or |A2> and |B2>

3. T(|A1>+|A2>)=T|A1>+T|A2>

Let's just rewrite the equations above (another better explanation is given in the video with the way you are going and how it changes if you change the initial rotation):

'(2×5)+(3×5)' is the same as '5×(3+2)'
'(2 and 5) or (3 and 5)' is the same as '5 and (2 or 3)'

T and (|A1> or |A2>) = T and (|A1>) or T and (|A2>)

Teleporting is much less credible than cloning.

Enter in that machine and trust us, you will disappear (die) and you will re-appear there (a copy made from your actual body parts that we tele-transported and brought back skillfully.

A clone, good enough to not reject organ transplant, is the necessary result of growing a new person from your DNA. That person would be much younger than you and will not know anything you learned since you are born.

Your proof is irrelevant, it is proving nothing if we realize that quantum superposition is not used by biological animals to think, for consciousness and all other brain activity.

A more credible proof reside in the nature of memory. A good clone which would recreate a brain with all the same connection would still miss part of what makes you with the emotions associated with each memory.

The reason is that brains use two methods to build memory. The first one is the actual synapse between neurons which can be grown or destroyed to modify the synchronous firing of multiple neurons. Such connection could be cloned if the resolution of the scanner/printer is fine enough for reproducing all connections.

The second method to build memory consist is modifying the gradient of chemical inside synapses. These changes are not physically detectable by any scanner. Furthermore, we can assume that a scanner would take days to completely read every detail of your brain then the 3D printer would take days to build a new copy. This timing difference is enough to interfere with that second kind of memory.

We don't need to perfectly clone a human brain to have the same memories. We don't need to perfectly clone a computer, at the quantum level, to run the same software on it, in a bit-exact manner. If that was the case, parallel programming would be impossible. But, it's not only possible, it's how nearly all modern services are, from Google to Facebook, to my 3D software and robot control system...
All we need is a software-level "memcpy()". We don't care if all the atoms inside the CPU and RAM will have the same quantum states, as long as they represent the same bit values.
Sure, the human brain is not binary, but If it depended on quantum properties so much that it was impossible to copy our memories, it would not have the insane plasticity / redundancy it does.
Such a fragile system would have never survived billions of years of evolution and tough environments.

teleportation is a form of cloning. 1 Reaoning why perfect cloning is not possible is below:
_
In order to clone something perfectly, you need to do it either instantly...or know the future in advance. Why. Because cloning requires information to be transferred from one object to another, and that takes time. Universe has a speed limit.
If the cloning process is not instant, and takes time, then the source object will "move on/change" during the information transfer, so that the cloned object will be the source object, but in the past. To get a perfect clone, you would need to transmit information instantly ,or compensate the delay by predicting the source object's position in the future.

Just one question: The basis of your explanation relies heavily on the word "chance"
However, everything in the universe that we know of works because of reasons, (when i push a block, it moves in the direction of my force, there is no chance it will not move, if my force is sufficient). We invented the term chance for mathematical reasons, when our knowledge of something is insufficient, we use "chances" to predict/ guess the outcome without actually knowing the outcome or the fully reason for an outcome. (when you play russian roulette, we know there is a 1/9 chance of dying, but we dont actually know in which slot the bullet is) Hence, chances are only used for prediction, it is not accurate, but the best tool we got for guess work. Hence, why would you use something that is not real (imaginary chances, example: 50%, 30%, etc) to prove something that is real (something occurs) to be false or true?

Is that even possible, even as a thought experiment?

Even if we had a device to perform such measurement, which would (presumably?) need to account for everything, a "god machine", the fact that it would beed to be part of the universe to perform a measurement would necessarily (presumably?) alter the data to be measured (can we measure without altering anything at all?) and the process would go in a eternal recursive loop to reassess its own alteration. The no cloning theorem has really nothing to do with accurately cloning the human brain. Arbitrary unknown quantum states have zero role in generating consciousness. Based on today's understanding of how consciousness arises in the brain, you need only recreate the neuro-anatomical structures on the cellular level to completely duplicate a person. The brain is messy, cells constantly die and are replaced. That's why the brain is full of redundancy, and error correction mechanisms, you wouldn't even have to be that careful to make a virtually exact duplicate. Data on a flash drive is far denser than in the human brain, you don't need to replicate the way each electron interacts with every lattice of silicon atoms to clone a flash drive....

So it IS feasibly possible for two things in the universe to be exactly the same, just not for us to make exact copies of something that there's only one of in existence. This brings to light an interesting concept concerning consciousness.

Suppose that the universe is spatially infinite. Also, suppose that the number of types of particles that exist in the universe is finite. On top of that, assume that there's only a certain number of ways to arrange those particles that complies with known physical law, and that those particles can only exist in a finite number of states. As such, if space is infinite, that would mean that, if you go far enough in any direction, you'll eventually run across an exact copy of the place you just left. So, if you left earth, then eventually you'd run across an exact replica of earth. Down to the people on it. Down to the arrangement of the neurons in those peoples' brains. Down to the properties of the sodium and potassium ions in those brains. And not only would there be one exact copy. If space were infinite, there would be an infinite number of exact copies.

Now, as far as we know of today, there is no mystical aspect of consciousness that determines its properties. You are you simply because your brain is arranged a certain way, and your neurons are firing in a particular pattern that is unique to you. But here's the catch - if there were to exist an exact copy of you, down to the position of the neurons and the arrangement of the neural activity, then which "you" would you be? Which head would you reside in? What would differentiate your mind from the mind of the other you? Assuming that they truly were an exact copy, then nothing at all would differentiate the two of you.

Now, if you two were to be in the same location and interacting with each other, then it could be determined which "you" was you, as the very act of interacting would break the symmetry. The other "you" would respond to your gestures, therefore altering his neural state in a way that's unique from yours. But, if the two of you were to forever remain isolated in your little bubbles, then you could conceivably reside in both heads at once. And, if there's an infinite number of "you's" out there, then you'd reside in all of their heads at once. And, since they'd all be exact copies, then they'd all be experiencing and doing the same thing simultaneously. So there wouldn't be any way for you to differentiate between the copies.

In short, your mind could be simultaneously existing in an infinite number of locations at once. You simply don't know because each location is an exact copy of the other, so you get the exact same sensory input and experience the exact same responses to that input at every location.

What's more, let's assume that every copy of you suddenly became curious and said "I want to find this supposed replica-world." Afterwards, they all set out in their collective high-tech spacecraft in a random direction, intent on traveling until they run across the replica-earth. Now, let's say that after an arbitrarily long amount of time (assuming that you could somehow do it before the universe suffered heat death) you finally run across this replica world. Here's the kicker. The "you" of this world would've left long ago, at the exact moment YOU decided to leave, in search of this mysterious "replica-world" he thought of. That means that, from the perspective of the people that inhabit that world, "you" set off in one direction, bound for a replica-world, but instead simply returned to your own world, coming from the opposite direction. From their perspective, you simply would've circled the entire universe, then come back around. And the crazy thing is that, from your perspective, this would be a perfectly reasonable explanation as well, as you'd never run in to any copy of you, and there would be no way of differentiating the earth you find from the earth you left behind. Similarly, a copy of you would show up on the earth you left, which the people on that world would assume was you after having circled the entire universe. So is there really any difference between a universe with an infinite number of "you"s and "earth"s, and a universe that curves in on itself?

I really don't think we should fuck with teleportation. To say with certainty that the same person came out the other end would be to assume something about the nature of life and death that we cannot possibly know. The only way for teleportation to not just kill one person and create a new indistinguishable one would be for a "soul" to exist and to somehow be transferred along with the physical body. The scariest thing is that there would be literally no possible way to know if "real" teleportation had been achieved because the resulting person would be completely indistinguishable from the original both to itself and all other possible measurements. The original person could just cease to exist (or pass on to an afterlife if such a thing exists) and be replaced by a new being that has all of that person's memories, and thus has no reason to think that they are not the original. This whole thing would also raise questions about what defines an object. If two things are literally indistinguishable, does that make them the same? All that is way too deep and scary for me to comfortably consider a possibility.

Henry,

I really am a fan of your videos, but this one is just plain wrong on a mathematical level, so I really wanted to point this out so that you know and that your viewer do not make the same mistake.

First of, proving that A is false by supposing that A is true then deriving a contradiction is not reasoning by absurd.
Absurd is when you want to prove that A is true, you suppose A is false, derive a contradiction and then obtain that A is true. It uses what we call classical logic/excluded middle axiom which is not constructive (that means you prove something exist, but cannot build it).
What you did, on the other hand, is using the very definition of "A is false" : If I suppose A true, then there is a contradiction (False is contradiction, "A is false" is "A -> False")
This matter because it doesn't use classical logic and such reasoning are thereby constructive
(Of course, that is not to say you cannot prove it using absurd, just that it is unnecessary, overcomplicated and brings unwanted consequences)

The other point I saw coming miles ago.
You present a set of axioms, mainly that any state can be written as a sum of product, and that any transformation on those set is linear with respect to multiplication.
So what's the problem?
You did not present any property on those multiplication and addition! So I do not have any idea on how they behave, specifically: I do not know that multiplication is commutative with respect to addition.
So I cannot conclude that (A + B) * (A + B) is not A*A + B*B
And then again, perhaps multiplication is commutative, but there is no reason I should conclude (A + B) * (A + B) can never be A*A + B*B, because perhaps there are rules that states that A*B and B*A can be zero (By convention, when you use the symbol * you suppose there is such a null element).

I really learn a lot through your videos, because I don't know much of physics, but I wanted to point this out because those are easily made mistakes in vulgarisation.

Thank you so much and have an happy new year ;)
Cheers!

Ugh, you completely lost my interest (well, I still watched the rest of the video, but with more disdain than I had when I started, anyway) when you blathered on about Schrodinger's Cat. It's completely absurd, which was Schrodinger's intention. It's incredibly idiotic to believe that it's true, and also incredibly egotistical. No matter what we Humans know, no matter what we can test, things still are one way or the other. The cat is either dead or alive, not both, never both.

Even if nobody knows the cat is alive, it's still alive, and vice versa. Inside the box, regardless of what we can observe from the outside, something is still happening. I mean, I suppose you could say "From the outside of the box, for all intents and purposes, the cat is both alive and dead, though within the box, only one is true." But what's the point? Still, when it comes down to it, the cat was never alive and dead simultaneously. Because that's impossible.

Let's go with this one: "My neighbours down the street are both alive and dead right now." Could be that they died, how would I know? Could be that they're alive, how would I know? From right here, I can't tell either way, so I guess they must be both alive and dead, right? No, because that's idiotic. My neighbours know damn well that they haven't been killed, the cat knows damn well that the gunpowder hasn't exploded.

Knowledge of something doesn't change whether or not it's happened. If a tree falls in the forest, and nobody is around to hear it, it still fell.

Teleportation is basically giving away the structure of your body(to the minutest level) to a computer, and then giving up your body itself so that each atom can be fired across the universe at the speed of light, allowing a computer to neatly (re)arrange all of those atoms to make an exact copy of you.

Is this the same as being born? No, because when you're born, your atoms are configured in such a way that they hold no memory. (But they do hold information(eg. instincts)).
Now let's get to the interesting part. We know that EVERY atom in one's body is replaced in a cycle of 5 years. So 5 years from now, you will be a different collection of atoms with a similar configuration. What is this configuration? This 'arrangement' of atoms is the only thing that allows you to experience the Universe. Any other configuration would not be you, and if this arrangement ceases to exit, so will you. But a lot of arrangements
WITHIN ourselves also keep changing. So what is the constant that keeps you, YOU? The soul?

No one quite knows. And this is perhaps the most important question in Science. What is the constant which continues to exist till you do, and is only unique to you such that it cannot be replicated? And does a teleportation device have the ability to replicate this constant?

What operator do you mean by multiplying in this case? The operator is acting on two state vectors which are fully distinct from one another (exploded and not exploded), in which case, these state vectors are orthogonal to one another. If you are taking this 'multiplication' to mean an inner product, then the 'product' of exploded and not exploded will be zero, since the state vectors are orthogonal, meaning the extra quadratic term in exploded and not exploded disappears, maintaining linearity for the cloning operator

It seems this wouldn't necessarily prevent Star Trek style replicators, though. If you replicate a Tea, Earl Grey, Hot, then it doesn't need to be a clone that matches the original at the quantum level; it just needs to have the same properties at the macro scale. So I think if you can synthesize a bunch of atoms of the right elements, and then put the right quantities of those atoms in the right positions, then you can make a replicators. The subatomic details may matter if you want to clone a mind, memories intact, but they probably don't if all you want is a nice cup of tea.

For two objects to be "identical" in the strictest sense of the term, they would have to occupy the same space at the same time. That would violate the Pauli exclusion principle. Even if you relax your definition of "identical" to allow for different positions, the Heisenberg uncertainty principle prevents you from knowing all the properties of any object simultaneously. So, you would never actually be able to know that two objects are identical in all respects.

I'd like to ask a basic question regarding the proof that was presented : When considering the cloning process you state that it should not be possible, since A^2 + B^2 != A^2 + B^2 + AB + BA, which if perfectly fine - given that A and B are real numbers ( maybe complex ones as well, would need to double check). However, A and B in this case represent probability densities - and even more so- they represent conditional probability densities. To explain myself a bit better, using the same analogy of multiplication being a product, whenever you say A*B  ( representing exploded and non-exploded states) you actually mean you would have a composite system between exploded and non-exploded gunpowder. Mind you, you're not saying you have a superimposition of these two states, but a composite system. And here's where things get tricky : the conditional probability of the gunpowder having exploded given that it has not exploded is zero and vice-versa. Therefore, A*B = B*A = 0. Even more interestingly so, B*B = B and A*A = A ( the probability of exploding given that it's exploded is one and the probability of it not exploding given that it has not exploded is also 1). Hence, if the cloning process were applied, it would result in a superimposition of probability densities A+B. Wouldn't this analysis be more accurate ?

One possible difficulty with your proof of no-cloning is whether or not composite states can commute. That is, is it true that |a>x|b> = |b>x|a> ? If it is, or if there is no necessary commutation relationship at all, then the proof works fine. However, I feel it needs to be shown, or at least demonstrated, that |a>x|b> != -|b>x|a>; that is, that composition is not anticommutative. If composition anti-commutes, then you can have cloning.

But why would cloning equate to squaring? Shouldn't it be doubling, since they're practically synonyms? Therefore, the proof would be:
1. Suppose cloning is possible
2. clone(A+B) = 2(A+B)
= clone(A)+clone(B) = 2A+2B
3. No contradiction
4. "cloning is possible" is true
The only flaw in this is Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle, which I don't have an answer for.

What if you were okay with incorrect copies as long as one was correct? For example: to get a perfect clone of Schrodinger's Cat, you would need to make two copies. You wouldn't know which copy is the correct one, but you would have a perfect clone. The same would apply to cloning a person. There is a finite number of atoms in a person and a finite number of positions for each particle of each atom. That combination is an absurdly huge number, BUT it is still a finite number.

yeah but the idea of making clones out of known clones assumes they are clones to begin with. even if you measure the properties of 2 atoms individually to deduce their mutual properties, you could only do so if they were entangled. and if they're strongly entangled then there's no reason to consider them separate particles. likewise your cloning machine would itself have to be entangled with the particles it creates, because of the necessary exhaustion of precision in making perfect clones, and so it too would essentially be part of the 'clones' it creates. therefore it seems we are simply playing word games with the properties of categories, mulling over the 'trivialities' of arithmetic, and expressing it as if it is all the result of the 'quirky' nature of quantum mechanics rather than our own extrapolated sense of what it means to be 'a single unique thing'.

actually, this is technically a proof by contradiction proving that the notion of 'clone' itself is contradictory, (that or the notion of individuality) but perhaps that's being rigid and unfun. to get a sense of how trivial all this is, just consider a layman definition: a clone is something that is identical in every way to something else, but it's still not that thing. the idea is simply nonsensical, which i guess is why this video proves that they don't exist by assuming they do.

For example, the transformation of "cutting in two" a potato which is in two state (cooked and not cooked, or A and B)
T(A + B) = (A1 + B1) x (A2 + B2)
T(A) + T(B) = A1xA2 + B1xB2

where A1 is the first half of the potato cooked, and B1 first half of the potato not cooked...
and we can imply this superposition of cooked/Not cooked, by a similar process of Schrodinger's one (exploded/not exploded).

So here's the thing; I didn't finish the video, but I noticed people commenting on the longer format, so I had a suspicion and skipped to the end. Turned out I was right, and you had asked people to comment about how they felt about the longer video. This is a problem, because most of the people who didn't particularly feel like sitting through it probably didn't, so you're going to get some pretty biased feedback.

Anyways, I don't mind longer science videos, but it's about expectations. I'm tired right now, and generally would not click on something intellectual that I thought was going to be long and require extended concentration. Minute Physics videos are usually good for this, because they are interesting and short. But when I'm feeling how I am today and click on this video, only to realize 5 minutes in that I've spaced out and completely lost where the video was going, I'm pretty much just going to give up and click away. So what it really comes down to is expectations: Your channel advertises "minutes physics", and while many of the people who would like "10 minute physics" are still likely to subscribe to your channel, they are also more likely to be disappointed when they realized they didn't get what they wanted, just as a person who orders a hamburger is probably going to be disappointed if they get a hotdog, even if they also like hotdogs.

OK, I understand why people use the proof by contradiction method, but something about using it bothers me.   We only know a fraction of a fraction of all the things there is to know about the universe, so that being said, couldn't the things we dont know contradict the things we do know?  Like what if, for instance we only "know" 1% of the universe, Could the 99% we dont know contradict the 1% we do "know"?   Plus, since we dont know everything, what if there is something we are overlooking? Like ok, fine, quantum physics has been tried and tested by honorable people, but remember, for the longest time scientist believed the earth was flat, and also drawing blood cures people from illness, and these "scientist" had proofs and at the time with only the knowledge they knew came to that conclusion.  So who's to say that cant happen with quantum physics?   My point is, we dont know everything, so how can proving by contradicting with a theory that we know zilch about, be a reasonable way to disprove cloning, or anything for that matter?  It's fun to talk about things like this, but how can we say things like this definitely?

I think that Physics is an easy topic to stretch into hours and hours of really interesting content. It's an incredible subject that I really enjoy learning more about. But I think there is a problem to longer videos that I will also provide a suggestion to solve.

Problem: In my opinion, it was your ability to compact complicated subjects into an easy-to-follow, short, cleverly illustrated video that really drew me to your channel. Perhaps the same goes for other people. Your content was fantastically laid out so that a large crowd could easily get on board and learn more about the universe (or race walking!) without spending hours or years just trying to wrap their heads around the fundamentals as presented in the most dry of texts. (Although I did pick up Time Reborn and it was really fantastic!)

Suggestion: I am not a YouTuber and I only know what little about making money off of the site as other YouTubers care to divulge. My understanding is that watch time and video duration does count for something and I would not blame you for needing to take advantage of this. So, perhaps instead of a long video on a single topic, how about a long video that goes over a couple of, perhaps, related topics? That way you can keep the shorter lessons but in a way that will still be economically beneficial for you? (If, indeed, that is the reason. I am only assuming).

Either way, I, personally, still look forward to your content! Long or short, it's a nice treat to learn more about the universe on all different scales.

This is NOT a proof by contradiction. Your explanation of PBC is correct, but proving that something is false by assuming it, then deriving a contradiction, is just proving that thing false. That's literally the definition of negation (see https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/negation#in_categorical_semantics), not a special proof technique at all. Notice at 6:29 you have a step 4 where you appeal to classical logic in order to cancel out the double negation. You did not do this in either your no-cloning proof, nor your no biggest even number proof, and so neither are PBCs, they are simply proofs of negation.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_principle

"Historically, the uncertainty principle has been confused with a somewhat similar effect in physics, called the observer effect,
which notes that measurements of certain systems cannot be made without
affecting the systems, that is, without changing something in a system.
Heisenberg offered such an observer effect at the quantum level (see
below) as a physical "explanation" of quantum uncertainty.[7] It has since become clear, however, that the uncertainty principle is inherent in the properties of all wave-like systems,[8] and that it arises in quantum mechanics simply due to the matter wave nature of all quantum objects. Thus, the
uncertainty principle actually states a fundamental property of quantum
systems, and is not a statement about the observational success of
current technology.[9] It must be emphasized that measurement
does not mean only a process in which a physicist-observer takes part,
but rather any interaction between classical and quantum objects
regardless of any observer."

This only proves that cloning without by-products is impossible, you can hypothetically still have exact cloning accompanied by ( a lot of ) other stuff.

This proof makes a strong assumption that the cloning machine doesn't measure or interact with the object passing through it during the process of cloning it. However, a much more realistic assumption (especially considering the constraint given that the machine does not know before the cloning what the object being cloned is) would be that the cloning machine has to measure the properties of the object it is cloning as it passes through. While this makes cloning of this method impossible due to the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle, the invocation of superpositions here is not particular relevant as the machine would necessarily have to collapse the superposition of the gunpowder to identify the outcome it needs to produce, thus removing the quantum mechanical complications. If anyone has a better explanation using superpositions and why the superposition could remain stable through the process, I'd love to hear it, but this entire proof seems tenuous at best. Also, cloning is still impossible so don't get your hopes up.
